message: It will be my first time, would be interesting to know what will happen within the Django sprint?
I'm probably going to be working on getting PyPy ready for a 1.5 release, and then profiling the django test suite on pypy
And it'd be a good idea to make that a git clone so you have the repo history and all branches/tags at your fingertips
maybe even roll the final release from there.
We'll probably be working on hammering out the last of the 1.3 stuff
have a fresh checkout of Django, read the contributing docs (not a huge deal, they'll be a sprint intro and a core dev will explain all the process stuff)
checkout is a little important since intenet might get slammed :)
a full git-svn co takes forever, and slams our server a bit
murphy willing @coderanger will put pypy and django in the same room so I can multitask effectively :)
@alex thanks Alex! I'm planning on participating to the sprint, anything I could do to prepare before hand? Would like to make the most of it and hopefully make myself useful.
use the django/django repo on github though, not a git-svn one
er yeah, via django/django
or take away his pony
thought it was a pink unicorn :)
contributing sounds a bit intimidating right now, hopefully after the event is over it will be different

@alex thanks! So from what I understand all I need is http://code.djangoproject.com/wiki/Version1.3Roadmap and this http://code.djangoproject.com/query?status=new&status=assigned&status=reopened&milestone=1.3 ? and a fresh git checkout before the sprint :)
@jamespaxi Don't worry, @alex only bites if we forget to feed him.
@jamespaxi The pony has many guises
@coderanger maybe a good meal and a beer? :)
Does it make sense to participate over IRC?
@miloshadzic absolutely.
Cool, I will be there! :)
Are there any other online resources for following what's going on with the various sprints besides IRC?
That's always been the main mechanism in the past. Maybe people will use convore this year?
